{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Abigail Disney | image = Abigail Disney 120613-N-LE393-021 (7369107672).jpg | alt = | caption = Abigail Disney speaking in 2012 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|1|24}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles, California]], U.S. | death_date = |children = 4 | death_place = |spouse = {{marriage|Pierre Norman Hauser|1988}} | nationality = | other_names = |family = [[Disney family|Disney]] | education = [[Yale University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Stanford University]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]])
[[Columbia University]] ([[PhD]]) | known_for = ''[[Pray the Devil Back to Hell]]'' | occupation = Filmmaker and philanthropist | parents = [[Roy E. Disney]]
Patricia Ann Dailey }} '''Abigail E. Disney''' (born January 24, 1960 in [[Los Angeles, California]]) is an American [[documentary]] filmmaker, philanthropist, and activist known for her documentary films focused on social themes. She is the Executive Producer and Director of the film ''The Armor of Light'', which premiered at the 2015 [[Tribeca Film Festival]].{{cite web|title=The Armor of Light {{!}} Tribeca Film Festival |url=https://tribecafilm.com/filmguide/armor-of-light-2015 |publisher=Tribecafilm.com |accessdate=2015-09-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003011259/https://tribecafilm.com/filmguide/armor-of-light-2015 |archivedate=October 3, 2015 |df=mdy }}{{cite web|title = The armor of light|url = http://armoroflightfilm.com/the-team/|website = THE ARMOR OF LIGHT|accessdate = 2015-09-30}} == Biography == ===Early life=== Abigail Disney was raised in [[North Hollywood, California]], and was educated at [[Yale]] (BA), [[Stanford University|Stanford]] (MA, [[English literature|English Lit]]), and [[Columbia University|Columbia]] (PhD, English Lit).[http://newsroom.ucr.edu/2618 UCR Newsroom: Award-winning Filmmaker to Speak at UCR]. Newsroom.ucr.edu (April 27, 2011). Retrieved on 2012-03-28. She is the daughter of Patricia Ann (née Dailey) and [[Roy E. Disney]] and granddaughter of [[Roy O. Disney]], co-founder of [[The Walt Disney Company]] with her great uncle [[Walt Disney]].[https://www.forbes.com/2010/08/19/abigail-disney-women-war-forbes-woman-power-women-documentary-film.html Abigail Disney Isn't Interested In Cinderella Stories]. Forbes.com (August 19, 2010). Retrieved on 2012-03-28. ===Career=== ==== Filmmaking ==== She turned to the family business of filmmaking with a documentary film, ''Pray the Devil Back to Hell'', directed by [[Academy Award]]-nominated, [[Emmy Award|Emmy]]-winning filmmaker Gini Reticker.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/wideangle/uncategorized/women-war-peace-about-the-producers/4089/ |title=Women, War & Peace ~ About the Producers : Wide Angle |publisher=Pbs.org |date=2009-01-21 |accessdate=2015-10-22}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://praythedevilbacktohell.com/ |title=Pray the Devil Back to Hell |publisher=Pray the Devil Back to Hell |date= |accessdate=2015-10-22}}{{cite web|url=http://forkfilms.net/about/#42-staff/1/612-gini-reticker |title=About |publisher=Fork Films |date= |accessdate=2015-10-22}} ''Pray the Devil Back to Hell'' brought to light the work of Liberian [[peace]] activist [[Leymah Gbowee]] by telling the story about the critical role women played in bringing peace to war torn [[Liberia]]. ''Pray the Devil Back to Hell'' won Best Documentary at the Tribeca Film Festival in 2008, and screened in 60 countries around the world on all seven continents.{{cite web|title = Pray the Devil Back to Hell {{!}} Tribeca Film Festival|url = https://tribecafilm.com/filmguide/archive/512ce84d1c7d76e046000e51-pray-the-devil-back-to-he|website = Tribeca|accessdate = 2015-09-30}}{{cite web|title = Pray the Devil Back to Hell: Filmmakers|url = http://praythedevilbacktohell.com/filmmakers.php|website = praythedevilbacktohell.com|accessdate = 2015-09-30|first = Fork Films|last = LLC}} In 2007, she and Gini Reticker founded [[Fork Films]], a New York-based production company that seeks to shed light, evoke compassion, stir action and build peace. She is the President and CEO, and Reticker is the Chief Creative Officer.{{cite web|url=http://forkfilms.net/about/ |title=About |publisher=Fork Films |date= |accessdate=2015-10-22}} In 2009, Fork Films and Film Sprout partnered together to create ''Pray the Devil Back to Hell''{{'s}} Global Peace Tour, a nine-month grassroots screening tour that culminated on the [[United Nations]]' International Day of Peace on September 21, 2009. In total, the tour brought the film to 31 foreign countries, 45 U.S. states and 235 U.S. cities.{{cite web|title=Pray the Devil Back to Hell: Global Peace Tour |url=http://praythedevilbacktohell.com/globalpeacetour.php |website=Praythedevilbacktohell.com |accessdate=2015-09-30 |first=Fork Films |last=LLC |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151004165126/http://praythedevilbacktohell.com/globalpeacetour.php |archivedate=October 4, 2015 |df=mdy }} The film is broadly credited with highlighting the bravery and sacrifice of its lead figure, Leymah Gbowee, who received a Nobel Peace Prize in 2011. The response to ''Pray the Devil Back to Hell'' led Disney to work on the five-part special series for [[PBS]], ''Women, War & Peace'', which aired in 2011 and was the winner of the Overseas Press Club's [[Edward R. Murrow]] Award, a Gracie Award, a Television Academy Honor and the America Bar Association's Silver Gavel Award (for ''I Came to Testify''). This series created and executive produced by Abigail Disney, Pamela Hogan and Gini Reticker looked at the role of women in war in the modern age, not just as victims of conflict, but as active agents for peace in their communities. Also in 2011, Disney received an [[Athena Film Festival]] Award for her extraordinary use of film for social change.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/women-war-and-peace/ |title=Women, War and Peace |publisher=PBS |date= |accessdate=2015-10-22}}{{cite web|url=http://athenafilmfestival.com/ |title=February 18-21, 2016 New York City |publisher=Athena Film Festival |date= |accessdate=2015-10-22}} Disney executive produced ''The Trials of Spring'' (2015), a major documentary event that includes a feature-length documentary, six short films, articles by award-winning journalists, and an ongoing robust social media conversation about women and their unwavering quest for social justice and freedom. The feature film, directed by Gini Reticker, chronicles the story of 21-year-old Hend Nafea, who sets out on a search for freedom and justice in a country gripped by a dangerous power struggle where there is little tolerance for the likes of her. The six short films were featured on ''[[The New York Times]]'' homepage in the six days leading up to the world premiere of ''The Trials of Spring'' at the [[Human Rights Watch]] Film Festival in New York City in June 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.trialsofspring.com/about |title=About | |publisher=Trialsofspring.com |date=2014-12-11 |accessdate=2015-10-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151014183028/http://www.trialsofspring.com/about |archivedate=October 14, 2015 |df=mdy }} Disney made her directorial debut with ''The Armor of Light,'' which follows pro-life [[evangelical Christianity|evangelical]] minister Rev. [[Rob Schenck]], [[Lucy McBath]], the mother of teenager [[Shooting of Jordan Davis|Jordan Davis]], and [[John Michael Phillips]]. Jordan Davis was gunned down in [[Jacksonville]], [[Florida]] on November 23, 2012. Davis was unarmed at the time of his death, and his story has cast a spotlight on "[[Stand-your-ground law|Stand Your Ground]]" laws in the United States. The film follows Rev. Schenck as he meets McBath, a pro-choice Christian, and her attorney John Phillips. It leads to the question: is it possible to be both pro-gun and pro-life? ''The Armor of Light'' premiered at the [[Tribeca Film Festival]] in April 2015 before opening theatrically on October 30, 2015.{{cite web|title = The armor of light|url = http://www.armoroflightfilm.com/|website = THE ARMOR OF LIGHT|accessdate = 2015-10-21|language = en}} In 2017, it was nominated for an Emmy Award. ==== Community activism and philanthropy ==== Disney and her husband Pierre Hauser created [http://www.daphnefoundation.org The Daphne Foundation] in 1991 in order to fund programs that confront the causes and consequences of poverty in the five boroughs of [[New York City]].{{cite web|title = About|url = http://www.daphnefoundation.org/about/|website = Daphne Foundation|accessdate = 2015-09-30}} In 2008, Disney launched [http://www.peaceisloud.org Peace is Loud], a nonprofit organization that inspires action through media and live events that spotlight women leaders on the frontlines of peacebuilding worldwide. The organization’s mission is to generate a groundswell of people committed to building a culture of peace. Disney serves as the Founder and President.{{cite web|title = Our Team|url = http://www.peaceisloud.org/our-team/|website = Peace is Loud|accessdate = 2015-09-30}} Disney has made several overseas trips with fellow peace activists, including [[Nobel Peace Prize|Nobel]] laureate Leymah Gbowee. The two traveled to the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] (DRC) in 2011 to spend a week working with women peace activists and to explore ideas for building peace in their country.{{cite web|title = Women Peacebuilders in the DRC – Nobel Women's Initiative|url = http://nobelwomensinitiative.org/2011/06/women-peacebuilders-in-the-drc/|website =Nobelwomensinitiative.org|accessdate = 2015-09-30}} The following year, they visited [[Sri Lanka]], where women activists launched the Sri Lankan Women's Agenda on Peace, Security and Development, inspired by Gbowee's legacy.{{cite web|url=http://www.africa.com/blog/a_local_girl_with_a_global_platform_leymah_gbowee_and_sri_lanka/ |title=A Local Girl with a Global Platform: Leymah Gbowee and Sri Lanka |publisher=Africa.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-22}} In 2012 she renounced her share of the profits from the Disney family investment in the [[Ahava]] cosmetics company whose factory is located in a [[West Bank]] settlement. She stated "I cannot in good conscience profit from what is technically the 'plunder' or 'pillage' of occupied natural resources..." For legal reasons she could not withdraw her investments and therefore donated the investments and profits "to organizations working to end this illegal exploitation."[http://www.jta.org/news/article/2012/07/16/3100916/disney-heir-renounces-profits-from-ahava "Disney heir renounces profits from Ahava"], [[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]], July 16, 2012. In May 2015, Disney joined Gbowee and 28 other international women peacebuilders to cross the 2-mile wide De-Militarized Zone (DMZ) separating [[North Korea|North]] and [[South Korea]] in an act of [[solidarity]] with Korean women and to call for an end to the [[Korean War]]. The peacebuilders headed international peace symposia in [[Pyongyang]] and [[Seoul]], where they listened to Korean women and shared experiences of mobilizing women to end conflict.{{cite web|title = WomenCrossDMZ Peace Walk 2015|url = https://www.womencrossdmz.org|website = Womencrossdmz.org|accessdate = 2015-09-30}} == Personal life == Disney married Pierre Norman Hauser in 1988 and has four children. Her first son is named Henry.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/10/09/style/abigail-disney-phd-candidate-weds-pierre-norman-hauser-2d-at-columbia.html |title=Abigail Disney, Ph.D Candidate, Weds Pierre Norman Hauser 2d at Columbia |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=1988-10-09 |accessdate=2015-10-22}}[https://www.forbes.com/2010/08/19/abigail-disney-women-war-forbes-woman-power-women ]{{dead link|date=October 2015}} She lives in New York City.{{cite web|url=http://nationalpeaceacademy.us/edresources/dialogues/npa-5th-birthday-with-abigail-disney/ |title=NPA 5th Birthday with Abigail Disney |publisher=Nationalpeaceacademy.us |date=2014-03-04 |accessdate=2015-10-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151122224713/http://nationalpeaceacademy.us/edresources/dialogues/npa-5th-birthday-with-abigail-disney/ |archivedate=November 22, 2015 |df=mdy }} == (2015) ;As director * ''[http://armoroflightfilm.com/ The Armor of Light]'' (2015) == Awards and recognition == === Awards === * The [[Women's Image Network Awards]] (2015) Woman of the Year Honoree{{Cite web|title = Women’s Image Network Announces Abigail Disney Woman of the Year Honoree {{!}} PRLog|url = http://www.prlog.org/12516199-womens-image-network-announces-abigail-disney-woman-of-the-year-honoree.html|website = www.prlog.org|accessdate = 2015-12-06}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/abigail-disney-irena-medavoy-honored-864417|title=Abigail Disney, Irena Medavoy Honored at Women's Image Awards|website=The Hollywood [[Women's Media Center]], with Gini Reticker * Crystal Award (2009), presented by The Victor E. Ward Educational Fund, with Gini Reticker and Leymah Gbowee * 2009 Auburn Lives of Commitment Award (2009), presented by [[Auburn Theological Seminary]] * Visionary Leader Award (2010), presented by Korean American Family Services Center * Mercy Center Honoree (2010), presented by Mercy Center * 2010 Honoree (2010), presented by [[Girl Scouts of the USA|Girl Scouts of America]] * Phoenix Award (2010), presented by New York Asian Women's Center * Visionary Social Change Award (2011), presented by [[Amref Health Africa|African Medical and Research Foundation]] (AMREF) * Athena Award (2011), presented by [[Barnard College]], the Athena Center for Leadership Studies and [[Athena Film Festival]], with Gini Reticker * International Advocate for Peace Award (2011), presented by [[Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law|Cardozo Law School]]'s Cardozo Journal of Conflict Resolution * 2012 [[Gracie Awards|Gracie Award]] for Outstanding Producer-News/Nonfiction for Women, War & Peace (2012), presented by The Gracie Awards * The James Park Morton Interfaith Award (2012), presented by the [[Interfaith Center of New York]], with Leymah Gbowee * Global Award for Media Leadership (2013), presented by Womensphere * Vanguard Award (2013), presented by Citizens' Committee for Children of New York * 2013 Honoree (2013), presented by YWLN * Leadership in Women's Philanthropy Award (2013), presented by The Dominican Women's Development Center * Morton Deutsch Award for Social Justice (2014), presented by the Morton Deutsch International Center for Cooperation and Conflict Resolution * Legacy Award (2014), presented by [[Women for Afghan Women]] * Public Health Change Champion Award (2014), presented by The Public Health Institute[http://www.armoroflightfilm.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/TheArmorOfLight_PressKit.pdf] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003200554/http://www.armoroflightfilm.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/TheArmorOfLight_PressKit.pdf |date=October 3, 2015 }} * IWMF (International Women's Media Foundation) Courage in Journalism Awards: Leadership Honoree (2015), presented by IWMF{{cite web|title = Intl. Women's Media Foundation Honors Disney, Deutsch|url = http://www.edgeatlanticcity.com/women//news//187278/intl_women's_media_foundation_honors_disney,_deutsch|website = EDGE Media Network|accessdate = 2015-10-21}} ===Honorary Degrees=== * [[Lawrence University]], Doctor of Humane Letters (2010) * [[Iona College (New York)|Iona College]], Doctor of Humane Letters (2010) * [[Cedar Crest College]] (2013) * [[The New School]] (2014) ===Boards=== * Current board member of Roy and Patricia Disney Family Foundation, the Fund for the City of New York, Search for Common Ground, Shining Hope for Communities, Peace is Loud and the [[Peace Research Endowment]]. * Former board member of [[The New York Women's Foundation]], [[The White House Project]] and the [[Global Fund for Women]]. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|2999307}} * [http://www.peaceisloud.org Peace is Loud] * [http://www.daphnefoundation.org Daphne Foundation] * [https://www.pbs.org/wnet/women-war-and-peace/ Women, War & Peace] * [http://forkfilms.net/ Fork Films] * [http://www.trialsofspring.com/ The Trials of Spring] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Disney, Abigail}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:American documentary film producers]] [[Category:American film producers]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Disney family|Abigail]] [[Category:People from North Hollywood, Los Angeles]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} '''Agnes Campbell, Lady Roseburn''' (1637 — 24 July 1716), Scottish businesswoman, was "Scotland's wealthiest early modern printer."<ref>Alastair J. Mann, [https://books.google.com/books?id=SRBkCOC8d-4C&lpg=PA53 "'A Mongrel of Early Copyright': Scotland in European Perspective"] in Ronan Deazley, Martin Kretschmer, and Lionel Bently, eds., ''Privilege and Property: Essays on the History of Copyright'' (Open Book Publishers 2010): 53. {{ISBN|9781906924188}}</ref>
==Early life== Agnes Campbell was the daughter of Isobel Orr and James Campbell. Her father was a merchant in [[Edinburgh, Scotland]]. She was baptized on 1 September 1637.<ref>Jane Rendall, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Zs6qBgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA62 "Agnes Campbell (Lady Roseburn)"] in Elizabeth Ewan, Sue Innes, and Sian Reynolds, eds., ''The Biographical Dictionary of Scottish Women'' (Edinburgh University Press 2006): 61-62. {{ISBN|9780748626601}}</ref>
==Career== Agnes Campbell married printer Andrew Anderson in 1656. In 1663, Anderson became printer to the Edinburgh Town Council, and in 1671, he was named [[Queen's Printer|King's Printer]] for Scotland. When her husband died in 1676, 38-year-old Agnes took over the exclusive licence<ref>Clare Jackson, [https://books.google.com/books?id=IUcT221m02sC&lpg=PA43 ''Restoration Scotland, 1660-1690: Royalist Politics, Religion and Ideas''] (Boydell Press 2003): 43. {{ISBN|9780851159300}}</ref> and built the largest printing business in Edinburgh.<ref>Adam Fox, [http://www.research.ed.ac.uk/portal/files/11876642/_Little_Story_Books_and_Small_Pamphlets_in_Edinburgh.pdf "'Little Story Books' and 'Small Pamphlets' in Edinburgh, 1680-1760: The Making of the Scottish Chapbook"] ''Scottish Historical Review'' 92(2)(2013): 207-230.</ref>
Agnes Campbell remarried in 1681.<ref>Deborah Simonton, [https://books.google.com/books?id=c8oTzX0_H60C&pg=PT116 "Widows and Wenches: Single Women in Eighteenth-Century Urban Economies"] in Deborah Simonton and Anne Montenach, eds., ''Female Agency in the Urban Economy: Gender in European Towns, 1640-1830'' (Routledge 2013): 116. {{ISBN|9781136275029}}</ref> In 1693, her petition to Parliament was granted, and Agnes Campbell's printing business remained independent from her second husband Patrick Telfer's financial oversight.<ref>Alastair J. Mann, "Book Commerce, Litigation and the Art of Monopoly: The Case of Agnes Campbell, Royal Printer, 1676-1712" ''Scottish Economic and Social History'' 18(2)(1998): 132-156. {{DOI|10.3366/sesh.1998.18.2.132}}</ref><ref>[http://www.rps.ac.uk/search.php?action=print&id=50636&filename=william_and_mary_trans&type=trans "Act in Favour of Agnes Campbell"] (1693), The Records of the Parliaments of Scotland to 1707, K.M. Brown et al eds (St Andrews, 2007-2015).</ref> She was [[Daniel Defoe]]'s Scottish printer, and published a folio edition of his poem "Caledonia."<ref>Paula R. Backscheider, [https://books.google.com/books?id=j9x8AlKeGGEC&pg=PA224 ''Daniel Defoe: His Life''] (Taylor & Francis 1992): 224. {{ISBN|9780801845123}}</ref><ref>Charles Eaton Burch, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/459125 "Defoe and his Northern Printers"] ''Proceedings of the Modern Language Association (PMLA)'' 60(1)(March 1945): 121-128. {{DOI|10.2307/459125}}</ref>
In 1709, she launched a paper mill at [[Penicuik]], the first paper mill on the [[River Esk (Lothian)|River Esk]].<ref>[http://www.penicuikpapermaking.org/mills.html Paper Mills] Penicuik Papermaking: 300th Anniversary.</ref> She was appointed printer the [[General Assembly of the Church of Scotland]] in 1712, around the same time that the King's Printer appointment expired and was granted to one of her rivals.<ref>Jane Rendall, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Zs6qBgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA62 "Agnes Campbell (Lady Roseburn)"] in Elizabeth Ewan, Sue Innes, and Sian Reynolds, eds., ''The Biographical Dictionary of Scottish Women'' (Edinburgh University Press 2006): 61-62. {{ISBN|9780748626601}}</ref>
==Personal life== Agnes Campbell was Presbyterian in religious affiliation.<ref>Warren McDougall, [https://books.google.com/books?id=OtiqBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA118 "Developing a Marketplace for Books: Edinburgh"] in Stephen Brown and Warren McDougall, eds., ''The Edinburgh History of the Book in Scotland Volume 2'' (Edinburgh University Press 2011): 118. {{ISBN|9780748628964}}</ref> She purchased an estate, Roseburn, in 1704, and was thereafter known as Lady Roseburn. She married twice, and had at least eight children. She died in July 1716, age 78, in Edinburgh, and left a significant fortune to her heirs.<ref>Alastair Mann, "Embroidery to Enterprise: The Role of Women in the Book Trade of Early Modern Scotland" in Elizabeth Ewan and Maureen M. Meikle, eds., [https://books.google.com/books?id=4Gm1AAAAIAAJ ''Women in Scotland, c. 1100 - c. 1750''] (Tuckwell Press 1999): 144. {{ISBN|9781862320468}}</ref>
A short biography of Lady Roseburn was published in 1925.<ref>John A. Fairley, [https://books.google.com/books?id=A56OGQAACAAJ ''Agnes Campbell, Lady Roseburn, Relict of Andrew Anderson, the King's Printer: A Contribution to the History of Printing in Scotland''] (D. Wyllie & Son 1925).</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} {{redirect|Toy Fair|Nuremberg Toy Fair|Nuremberg International Toy Fair}} {{Infobox Convention |name = American International Toy Fair |image = [[File:TIA 2006ToyFair Logo s.png|240px]] |caption = Toy Fair logo used in 2006 |status = Active |genre = Toys |venue = [[Jacob K. Javits Convention Center]] and [[Toy Center]] |location = New York City, [[New York (state)|New York]] |country = United States |first = February 1903 |organizer = [[Toy Industry Association]] |filing = |attendance = 30,000 in 2013 |website = {{url|toyfairny.com/}} }} The '''American International Toy Fair''' (stylized as '''TOY FAIR''') is an annual toy industry [[trade show]] held in mid-February in New York City's [[Jacob K. Javits Convention Center]] and at toy showrooms around the city. The event is open to the toy trade only – toy industry professionals, retailers, and press representatives. It is owned and managed by the [[Toy Industry Association]].<ref>[http://www.toy-tia.org/template.cfm Toy Industry Association] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060209031416/http://www.toy-tia.org/Template.cfm |date=February 9, 2006 }} main site</ref> Toy Fair's promoters describe it as the largest toy trade show in the Western hemisphere.
==History== Toy Fair began in February 1903. The first event featured less than ten toy companies with [[Lionel Corporation|Lionel]] [[toy train|trains]] among the featured products.<ref>Moore, Angela [http://articles.latimes.com/2003/feb/10/business/fi-toyfair10 It's Not All Child's Play at Toy Fair] ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' (February 10, 2003). Retrieved September 8, 2014.</ref> As the event expanded, more space was needed which led to toy companies occupying 200 Fifth Avenue, a [[Fifth Avenue Hotel|former hotel site]], in 1910. By 1925, it was renamed the [[Toy Center|International Toy Center]].<ref>Sanderson, Peter [http://www.ign.com/articles/2004/02/23/toy-fair-2004-day-one-batman-harry-potter-justice-league TOY FAIR 2004 DAY ONE: BATMAN, HARRY POTTER & JUSTICE LEAGUE] [[IGN]] (February 14, 2004). Retrieved September 8, 2014.</ref>
The 110th annual Toy Fair, held February 10–13, 2013, attracted more than 1,500 manufacturers, distributors, importers, and sales agents from 30 countries in over {{convert|300000|sqft|m2}} of exhibit space. Nearly 9,500 buyers from 5,000 retail outlets attended. Overall, there were an estimated 30,000 attendees from 92 countries.<ref>[http://www.toyassociation.org/PressRoom2/News/2013_News/American_International_Toy_Fair___February_10-13__2013___Welcomes_Surge_in_Global_Visitors.aspx#.UeLz1lNOnbQ American International Toy Fair – February 10–13, 2013 – Welcomes Surge in Global Visitors]. Toyassociation.org (February 19, 2013). Retrieved on 2013-07-19.</ref>
==Venues== [[Image:TIA 2006ToyFair Toy center dscn6859.jpg|right|thumb|240px|200 Fifth Avenue]] The Javits exhibits feature demonstrations and displays in an open trade show setting, while the toy district showrooms allow buyers to consult with sales representatives from the major toy manufacturers in a quieter setting. These showrooms can be found at
* 200 Fifth Avenue between 23rd & 24th Streets * 1107 Broadway at 24th Street * 230 Fifth Avenue between 26th & 27th Streets * 1115 Broadway at 25th Street
Each building (they are interconnected by upper story walkways) contains relatively small showrooms from many manufacturers. Products featured include current lines as well as samples of products not yet introduced, or products under development. Many manufacturers will stage receptions or events prior to the fair itself for invited buyers, media representatives, or dignitaries.
==Attendance== [[Image:TIA 2006ToyFair Decorated Bus dscn6883.jpg|right|thumb|240px|[[Troll doll|Trolls]] (toy) decorated bus]] Registration is open to the trade only. Admission for buyers is free, but proof of participation in the toy industry is required. Admission for toy manufacturer employees and media is not free, and credentials are required. Attendees must be aged 18 years or older.
==References== [[Image:TIA 2006ToyFair LEGO Batman Promo Dscn7058a.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Lego]] [[Batman]] promotional statue with [[Bionicle]] advert]] {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.toyfairny.com Toy Fair New York]
{{Toys}}
[[Category:1903 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1903]] [[Category:Trade shows in the United States]] [[Category:Economy of New York City]] [[Category:Toy industry]] [[Category:Festivals established in 1903]]

{{refimprove|date=November 2007}}
'''Anti-Money Laundering (AML) Software''' is [[software]] used in the [[finance]] and [[legal]] industries to meet the legal requirements for [[financial institutions]] and other regulated entities to prevent or report [[money laundering]] activities. There are four basic types of software that address anti-money laundering: transaction monitoring systems, [[currency transaction report]]ing (CTR) systems, customer identity management systems and compliance management software.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://complyadvantage.com/knowledgebase/anti-money-laundering/anti-money-laundering-software/|title=What Is Anti Money Laundering Software? I ComplyAdvantage|last=|first=|date=|work=ComplyAdvantage|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
==History== Anti-money laundering guidelines came into prominence globally after the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]] and the subsequent enactment of the [[USA PATRIOT Act]] in the United States and the establishment of the [[Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering]] (FATF). By 2010 many jurisdictions globally required [[financial institutions]] to monitor, investigate and report transactions of a suspicious nature to the financial intelligence unit in their respective country.
An entire industry developed around providing software to analyze transactions in an attempt to identify transactions or patterns of transactions, called [[structuring]], which requires a [[Suspicious activity report|SAR]] filing, or other suspicious patterns that qualify for SAR reporting. Financial institutions faced penalties for failing to properly file CTR and SAR reports, including heavy fines and regulatory restrictions, even to the point of charter revocation.
==Types== There are four basic types of software addressing AML business requirements: * Transaction monitoring systems, which focus on identification of suspicious patterns of transactions which may result in the filing of [[Suspicious Activity Report]]s (SARs) or Suspicious Transaction Reports (STRs). Identification of suspicious (as opposed to normal) transactions is part of the KYC requirements. * [[Currency Transaction Report]]ing (CTR) systems, which deal with large cash transaction reporting requirements ($10,000 and over in the U.S.) * Customer identity management systems which check various negative lists (such as [[OFAC]]) and represent an initial and ongoing part of [[Know your customer]] (KYC) requirements. Electronic verification can also check against other databases to provide positive confirmation of ID such as (in the UK: electoral roll; the "share" database used by banks and credit agencies; telephone lists; electricity supplier lists; post office delivery database * Compliance software to help firms comply with AML regulatory requirements; retain the necessary evidence of compliance; and deliver and record appropriate training of relevant staff. In addition, it should have audit trails of compliance officers activities in particular pertaining to the handling of alerts raised against customer activity.
===Transaction monitoring software=== These software applications effectively monitor bank customer transactions on a daily basis and, using customer historical information and account profile, provide a "whole picture" to the bank management. Transaction monitoring can include cash deposits and withdrawals, wire transfers and ACH activity. In the bank circles, these applications are known as "AML software".
Each vendor's software works somewhat differently. Some of the modules which should be present in an AML software are: *Know Your Customer *Entity Resolution *Transaction Monitoring *Compliance Reporting *Alert based case management *Investigation Tools *Document management to hold the customer related documentation such as account opening package, customer identification documents, etc... *Delivery of AML Training *Customer due diligence checks, including electronic verification *Automated Standard operating procedures e.g. workflow engine/ *Dissemination of AML policies and procedures
===Customer Identity Management Systems=== The definition for Customer Identity Management Systems varies in different regions and jurisdictions. Most vendors include the following features in their solutions: *Sanction List Check *Politically Exposed Person (PEP) Check *False Positive Recording *Single Scan and Batch Scanning *Auditing and Reporting
===Machine learning for money laundering detection=== There are solutions based on artificial intelligence, which are characterized by much better efficiency in detecting money laundering, comparing to rule-based approach. Especially, deep neural networks are able to discover complex interdependencies between various activities performed to launder money. This translates into fewer false alarms and more accurate detection. In the near future, transaction monitoring systems will be based on machine learning rather than on rules and scenarios.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Tomasz |last=Czech |title=Deep learning: the next frontier for money laundering detection |url=https://www.globalbankingandfinance.com/deep-learning-the-next-frontier-for-money-laundering-detection/ |journal=Global Banking and Finance Review }}</ref>
==Companies in Industry== *[https://www.synectics-solutions.com/anti-money-laundering Synectics Solutions] *[http://www.aml360software.com/ AML360] *[https://www.beamsolutions.com/ Beam Solutions] *[https://www.casewareanalytics.com/solutions/business-solutions/aml-compliance/ CaseWare Analytics] *Comarch *[https://complyadvantage.com/ ComplyAdvantage] *[https://www.csiweb.com/industries-we-serve/financial-institutions/regulatory-compliance/software/ CSI] *[http://www.eastnets.com EastNets] *Fiserv *[http://www.identitymind.com/ Identitymind] *[http://www.idetect-soft.eu/ idetect] *iFlex *[https://mlverify.com ML Verify] *[https://www.niceactimize.com/ Nice Actimize] *[https://www.NorthRow.com/ NorthRow] *[http://www.gv-systems.com/products-solutions/patriot-officer/ Patriot Officer] *[https://verafin.com/ Verafin] *[https://vneuron.com/ Vneuron] *[http://www.ebos.com.cy/Anti-Money-Laundering WiseBOS ERP AML] *[http://www.dimensiongrc.io/ Dimension GRC]
==See also== *[[Anti-money laundering]] *[[Bank regulation]] *[[Know your customer]] *[[Politically Exposed Person]] *[[Regulatory technology]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox person | name = Aung Thet Mann | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth-date and age|19 June 1977}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Burmese | other_names = | occupation = CEO of [[Ayer Shwe Wah]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | alma_mater = [[Yangon Institute of Economics]] | parents = [[Shwe Mann]] (father)
Khin Lay Thet | relatives = [[Toe Naing Mann]] (brother) | spouse = Khin Hnin Thandar }} '''Aung Thet Mann''' ({{lang-my|အောင်သက်မန်း}}, {{IPA-my|àuɴ θɛʔ máɴ|pron}}; born 19 June 1977{{cite web|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2008-02-11/html/E8-2425.htm|title=Additional Designations of Individuals Pursuant to Executive Order 13448|date=February 11, 2008|publisher=Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control |accessdate=11 July 2015}}), also known as '''Shwe Mann Ko Ko''' ({{my|ရွှေမန်းကိုကို}}), is a Burmese businessman and currently CEO of [[Ayer Shwe Wah]], a major Burmese company.{{cite web|url=http://aysw.com.mm/AyerShweWah/my/about-us|title=AYER SHWE WAH CO.,LTD COMPANY PROFILE|work=Ayer Shwe Wah Company|accessdate=11 July 2015}} Aung Thet Mann's father is [[Shwe Mann]], a former military general and Speaker of the [[Pyithu Hluttaw]].{{cite web|url=http://www.altsean.org/Research/SPDC%20Whos%20Who/SPDC/ShweMannhtm.htm|title=Shwe Mann|work=Alternative Asean Network on Burma|accessdate=11 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705003759/http://www.altsean.org/Research/SPDC%20Whos%20Who/SPDC/ShweMannhtm.htm|archive-date=2015-07-05|dead-url=yes|df=}} He graduated from the [[Yangon Institute of Economics]].{{cite news|url=http://www2.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=14151&page=3|title=Tracking the Tycoons|date=September 2008|work=The Irrawaddy|accessdate=11 July 2015}} Aung Thet Mann is married to Khin Hnin Thandar.{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32012D0098|title=COUNCIL DECISION 2012/98/CFSP of 17 February 2012 amending Decision 2010/232/CFSP renewing restrictive measures against Burma/Myanmar|date=17 February 2012|publisher=Council of the European Union|accessdate=11 July 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Burmese businesspeople]] [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Infobox royalty | name =Bedřich Pola | title =Count Pola | image = | caption = | spouse = Ludmila Eliáš | issue = Countess Kristina Pola
Count Martin Pola
Count Tomáš Pola
Countess Markéta Pola | full name =Bedřich Jan Bosco Filip Neri Pola | house =[[House of Pola]] | father =Count Bedřich Jaroslav Josef Antonín Pavel Pola | mother =Eliška Marie Třísková | birth_date ={{birth date|1963|11|9|df=y}} | birth_place =[[Brandýs nad Labem]], [[Czechoslovakia]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = | signature = | religion = [[Roman Catholic]] |}} RNDr. '''Bedřich Pola''' (also: {{lang-cs|Bedřich Jan Bosco Filip Neri hrabě Pola}}, {{lang-en|Frederick John Bosco Philip Neri, Count Pola}}) (9 November 1963), is a Czech entrepreneur, founder of the first private integrated circuit Development Centre in the [[Czech and Slovak Federative Republic]], Knight of Honour and Devotion of the [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta]] (SMOM), President of [[Maltézská pomoc, o.p.s.]][http://www.maltezskapomoc.cz/admin/files/ModuleText/20/vyrocni-zprava-2015.pdf Annual Report of Maltézská pomoc, o.p.s. 2015] (the humanitarian organization established by the SMOM's Grand Priory of Bohemia) and the owner of castle [[Bukovec (Domažlice District)|Bukovec]]. == Life == === Early life, education === Born in [[Brandýs nad Labem]] on 9 November 1963 into an ancient Italian noble family [[House of Pola|Pola]] (since 17th century living in Bohemia). He graduated from the [[Charles University in Prague]] in Physics. In 1987, he completed postgraduate studies, earning his [[RNDr.]] degree in [[electronics]]. === Family === In 1990, he married Ludmila ''née'' Eliáš, who is relative to the general [[Alois Eliáš]], who served as Prime Minister of the [[Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia]] from April 27, 1939 to September 28, 1941. Bedřich Pola has 4 children: Kristina (1990), Martin (1992), Tomáš (1993), Markéta (1997). In 2010, he became the owner of castle in [[Bukovec (Domažlice District)|Bukovec]]. == Career == In 1990, he founded the first private integrated circuit Development Centre in the [[Czech and Slovak Federative Republic]] [[ASIX s.r.o.]] In 2015 he became the President of Maltézská pomoc, o.p.s. (the humanitarian organization established by the SMOM's Grand Priory of Bohemia). ==Honours and awards== *{{flag|SMOM}}: Knight of Honour and Devotion of the [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta]] == Notes == Regarding personal names: ''Hrabě'' is a title, translated as ''Count'', not a first or middle name. The female form is ''Hraběnka''. ==Bibliography== * {{cite book |last1=Hübner |first1=Ralph |authorlink1=Ralph Hübner |title=Who is...? (v České Republice) |year=2013 |location=Nördlingen |isbn=978-3-7290-0121-3 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *http://www.turistika.cz/mista/zamek-bukovec *http://www.asix.cz/index_about_history.htm {{DEFAULTSORT:Pola, Count Bedrich}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Czech businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Charles University in Prague alumni]] [[Category:Knights of Malta]]

revision.text:
'''Boonpong Sirivejjabhandu''' [[George Cross|GC]], [[Member of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire|MBE]] ({{lang-th|บุญผ่อง สิริเวชชะพันธ์}}; {{RTGS|Bunphong Siriwetchaphan}}, 21 April 1906<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://event.thaipbs.or.th/event/index.php?q=node%2F659# |title=ย้อนประวัติ รู้จักกับบุญผ่อง จากไทยพีบีเอส |access-date=2018-11-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219054923/http://event.thaipbs.or.th/event/index.php?q=node%2F659# |archive-date=2013-12-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>{{spaced ndash}}29 January 1982<ref>[http://www.oknation.net/blog/boonpong/2013/05/05/entry-1 ลาก่อนเวรี่... ลาทีบุญผ่อง จากโอเคเนชั่น]</ref>) widely known as '''Boon Pong''' was a [[Thai people|Thai]] merchant and member of the underground "V" Organization during the [[Japan]]ese occupation of [[Thailand]] during [[World War II]].
==World War II==
Boon Pong, using as cover his contract with the Imperial Japanese Army to supply the canteens of [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] [[prisoners of war|POWs]] working along the [[Kwai Lo River]], smuggled medicine, money and contraband food to the POWs and is credited by many with saving thousands of lives during the building of the [[Burma Railway]].
Although Thailand made peace with the Japanese after being invaded, there was an active underground movement. One prisoner recalls Boonpong was the merchant with the lowest prices and the smallest mark up. However he performed other services risking his life and those of his family. He lent money, provided extra medicines and ran messages. With access to medicines, the death rate of the prisoners was reduced from five a day in May 1943 to one a week by the following November.
==Post-war==
After the war, Boonpong was attacked by Thai police in some mistaken retribution. Sir [[Edward Dunlop|Edward 'Weary' Dunlop]], another hero of the POW camps, ordered a report on 'the condition of Mr. Boonpong, injured Thai civilian, who had done so much for prisoners of war.’ In 1947 he was in financial difficulties and so a [[prisoner of war|POW]] association on hearing of it organised a collection for him. Shortly thereafter, Boonpong started the Boonpong Bus Company. In 1948 he was awarded the [[Member of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire|MBE]] by the British Government.<ref>[http://www.the-spiceislands.com/Thailand/boonpong.htm Biography] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070211143158/http://www.the-spiceislands.com/Thailand/boonpong.htm |date=February 11, 2007 }}</ref>
Later an Australian medical scholarship was named in honor of him and Sir Edward Dunlop. The documentary film “The Quiet Lions” is about both of them. Boonpong also figures prominently in ''Beyond the Bamboo Screen'', a collection of anecdotes by Scottish PoWs.
==In popular culture==
[[Rungsak Loychusak]] portrayed Boonpong Sirivejjabhandu in ''[[Boonpong]]'' a [[thai television soap opera]] based on the true story him. ''Boonpong'' was broadcast on [[Thai Public Broadcasting Service|Thai PBS]] during 8 May 2013 - 20 June 2013.
==See also== *[[Philip Toosey]]
==References== <references/> * [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/sunday/20051023/index.php?news=column_18702067.html BOOKS: Three cheers for the colonel] * ''Sort of a Cricket Person'' by E. W. Swanton - Collins - London - 1972 {{ISBN|0-00-211748-7}}.
==External links== *[http://www.shipsnostalgia.com/showthread.php?t=11466 Detailed information] *[http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,23543563-5001986,00.html "The Grocer" a brief excerpt regarding Boon Pong]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sirivejjabhandu, Boonpong}} [[Category:Thai businesspeople]] [[Category:Thai people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Military history of Thailand during World War II]]

{{Infobox theatre |name = Broadway Theatre |image = Promises Promises at Broadway Theatre.JPG |caption = The Broadway Theatre in 2010, when it staged to ''Promises, Promises'' |address = 1681 Broadway |city = New York City |country = United States |designation = |coordinates = {{coord|40.7633|-73.9831|type:landmark_region:US-NY_scale:2000|display=inline,title}} |architect = [[Eugene De Rosa]] |owner = [[The Shubert Organization]] |capacity = 1,761 |type = Broadway |opened = December 25, 1924 |yearsactive = |rebuilt = 1956
1986 |closed = |othernames = Universal's Colony Theatre
B.S. Moss' Broadway Theatre
Earl Carroll's Broadway Theatre
Ciné Roma |production = ''[[King Kong (2013 musical)|King Kong]]'' |currentuse = |website = [http://www.shubert.nyc/theatres/broadway www.shubert.nyc/theatres/broadway] }} [[File:Broadway Theatre NYC entrance.jpg|thumb|Entrance, showing ''[[The Color Purple (musical)|The Color Purple]]'']] [[File:4.28.11BroadwayTheatreByLuigiNovi.jpg|thumb|The Broadway Theatre during the run of ''[[Sister Act]]'', ca. 2011.]] The '''Broadway Theatre''' (formerly '''Universal's Colony Theatre''', '''B.S. Moss' Broadway Theatre''', '''Earl Carroll's Broadway Theatre''', and '''Ciné Roma''') is a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] [[Theater (building)|theatre]] located in [[midtown Manhattan]]. It has a large [[seating capacity]] of 1,761, and unlike most Broadway theaters, it is actually located on [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]], at number 1681. Designed by architect [[Eugene De Rosa]] for Benjamin S. Moss, it opened as ''B.S. Moss's Colony Theatre'' on [[Christmas Day]] 1924 as a venue for [[vaudeville]] shows and motion pictures. The theater has operated under many names and owners. It was renamed ''Universal's Colony Theatre'', ''B.S. Moss' Broadway Theatre'', and ''Earl Carroll's Broadway Theatre'' before becoming a [[legitimate theater]] house simply called ''Broadway Theatre'' on December 8, 1930. In 1937, known as ''Ciné Roma'', it showed [[Italian film]]s. For a short time during the 1950s it showed [[Cinerama]] films.{{cite web | title = Broadway Theater History | work =New York City Theater | year =2011 | url =http://www.newyorkcitytheatre.com/theaters/broadwaytheater/history.php| accessdate =February 14, 2012 }} On November 18, 1928 the first [[Mickey Mouse]] cartoon released to the public, [[Steamboat Willie]], debuted at the Colony. Producer [[Walt Disney]] returned on November 13, 1940 to debut the feature film ''[[Fantasia (1940 film)|Fantasia]]'' in [[Fantasound]], an early stereo system.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} The legitimate theater opened in 1930 with ''[[The New Yorkers]]'' by [[Cole Porter]]. Stars such as [[Milton Berle]], [[Alfred Drake]], [[José Ferrer]], [[Eartha Kitt]], [[Vivien Leigh]], [[Zero Mostel]], and [[Mae West]] have appeared on stage.{{cite web | title =The Broadway Theatre|publisher =New York TV Show Tickets Inc. | year =2008 | url =http://www.nytix.com/Links/Broadway/Theaters/broadway.html| accessdate =February 14, 2012}} [[The Shubert Organization]] bought the theater in 1939 and renovated it extensively in 1956 and 1986. It has long been a popular theatre for producers of [[musical theatre|musicals]] because of large seating capacity, and the large stage, which is nearly sixty feet deep. Often plays that have become successful in smaller theaters have transferred to the Broadway Theatre. ==Notable productions== *1928: ''[[Steamboat Willie]]'' *1930: ''[[The New Yorkers]]'' *1932: ''[[Earl Carroll's Vanities]]'' (starring [[Milton Berle]]) *1940: [[Walt Disney]]'s ''[[Fantasia (1940 film)|Fantasia]]'' *1941: ''[[Too Many Girls (musical)|Too Many Girls]]'' *1942: ''[[My Sister Eileen]]'' *1943: ''[[The Student Prince]]'' *1943: ''[[Carmen Jones]]'' (premiere) *1943: ''[[Lady in the Dark]]'', ''[[Damn Yankees]]'' *1946: ''[[Beggar's Holiday]]'' *1948: ''[[The Cradle Will Rock]]'', ''[[High Button Shoes]]'' *1951: ''[[Where's Charley?]]'', ''[[Oklahoma!]]'' *1952: ''[[Kiss Me, Kate]]'' *1953: ''[[South Pacific (musical)|South Pacific]]'' *1956: ''[[Mr. Wonderful (musical)|Mr. Wonderful]]'' *1957: ''[[The Most Happy Fella]]''; ''[[Shinbone Alley]]'' *1958: ''[[The Body Beautiful]]'' *1959: ''[[Gypsy (musical)|Gypsy]]'' *1960: ''[[The Music Man]]'' *1961: ''[[Fiorello!]]'', ''[[Grand Hotel (musical)|Grand Hotel]]'' *1962: ''[[My Fair Lady]]'', ''[[I Can Get It for You Wholesale]]'' *1963: ''[[The Girl Who Came to Supper]]'' *1965: ''[[Baker Street (musical)|Baker Street]]'' *1966: ''[[Funny Girl (musical)|Funny Girl]]'' *1968: ''[[Cabaret (musical)|Cabaret]]'' *1969: ''[[The Pirates of Penzance]]'' *1970: ''[[Fiddler on the Roof]]'' *1972: ''[[Dude (musical)|Dude]]'' *1974: ''[[Candide (operetta)|Candide]]'' *1976: ''[[Guys and Dolls]]'' *1977: ''[[The Wiz]]'' *1979: ''[[Evita (musical)|Evita]]'' *1983: ''[[Zorba (musical)|Zorba]]'' {| class="wikitable" !Production !First preview !Opening date !Closing date !Notes |- | ''[[The Three Musketeers (musical)|The Three Musketeers]]'' | October 26, 1984 | November 11, 1984 | November 18, 1984 | |- | ''[[The King and I]]'' | {{nowrap|December 26, 1984}} | January 7, 1985 | June 30, 1985 | |- | ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'' | February 28, 1987 | March 12, 1987 | October 14, 1990 | Moved to the [[Imperial Theatre]] three days later to run until May 18, 2003. |- | ''[[Miss Saigon]]'' | March 23, 1991 | April 11, 1991 | January 28, 2001 | |- | ''[[Blast! (musical)|Blast!]]'' | April 5, 2001 | April 17, 2001 | {{nowrap|September 23, 2001}} | |- | ''[[La bohème]]'' | November 29, 2002 | December 8, 2002 | June 29, 2003 | Staged by [[Baz Luhrmann]] |- | ''Sexaholix'' | {{n/a}} | November 11, 2003 | December 7, 2003 | |- | ''[[Bombay Dreams]]'' | March 29, 2004 | April 29, 2004 | January 1, 2005 | |- | ''[[The Color Purple (musical)|The Color Purple]]'' | November 1, 2005 | December 1, 2005 | February 24, 2008 | |- | ''[[Shrek The Musical]]'' | November 8, 2008 | {{nowrap|December 14, 2008}} | January 3, 2010 | |- | ''[[Promises, Promises (musical)|Promises, Promises]]'' | March 27, 2010 | April 25, 2010 | January 2, 2011 | |- | ''[[Sister Act (musical)|Sister Act]]'' | March 24, 2011 | April 20, 2011 | August 26, 2012 | |- | ''[[Cinderella (2013 Broadway production)|Cinderella]]'' | January 25, 2013 | March 3, 2013 | January 4, 2015 | |- | ''[[Doctor Zhivago (musical)|Doctor Zhivago]]'' | March 27, 2015 | April 21, 2015 | May 10, 2015 | |- | ''[[Fiddler on the Roof]]'' | November 20, 2015 | December 20, 2015 | December 31, 2016 | Fifth Broadway revival |- | ''[[Miss Saigon]]'' | March 1, 2017 | March 23, 2017 | January 14, 2018 | Limited engagement; first Broadway revival |- | ''Rocktopia | {{n/a}} | March 20, 2018 | April 29, 2018 | Limited engagement |- |''[[King Kong (2013 musical)|King Kong]]'' |October 5, 2018 |November 8, 2018 | | |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|The Broadway Theatre}} * {{Ibdb venue|id=1496|venue=The Broadway Theatre}} *[http://www.playbillvault.com/Theatre/Detail/390/Broadway-Theatre Broadway Theatre | PlaybillVault.com] *[http://www.newyorkcitytheatre.com/theaters/broadwaytheater/theater.html New York Theatre Guide] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060323111607/http://www.nytheatre.com/nytheatre/broadway.htm Broadway Theatre Venue Information] at nytheatre.com, an information resource guide to theatre in New York City published by the nonprofit New York Theatre Experience, Inc. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070923224523/http://www.nycago.org/Organs/NYC/html/ColonyTheater.html Skinner organ at the Colony Theater] *{{cite book|last =Wilmeth|first=Don B.|title=The Cambridge Guide to American Theatre|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2007|pages=128–129|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UYsXbFvjrXkC|isbn=978-0-521-83538-1}} {{TonyAwards venues}} {{Broadway theatres}} {{Broadway (Manhattan)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Broadway Theatre}} [[Category:Broadway theatre]] [[Category:Broadway theatres]] [[Category:Shubert Organization]] [[Category:Broadway (Manhattan)]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1924]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]]

{{About|the Detroit skyscraper Cadillac Tower|the attached skyscraper complex approved for construction|Cadillac Centre|the [[New Center]] Detroit skyscraper|Cadillac Place}} {{Infobox building | name = Cadillac Tower | image = BarlumTowerDetroit.jpg | former_name = Barlum Tower | completion_date = | architectural_style= | building_type = Commercial offices | location = | coordinates = {{coord|42.331976|-83.044893|region:US-MI_type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | roof = {{convert|133.4|m|abbr=on}} | antenna_spire = {{convert|176.2|m|abbr=on}} | floor_count = 40
2 below ground | floor_area = {{convert|31,773|m2|abbr=on}} | architect = | nrhp = {{Infobox NRHP | name =Barlum Tower |embed = yes | nrhp_type = | location= 65 Cadillac Square
[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] | built =1927 | builder = Otto Misch Co. | architect= Bonnah & Chaffee | architecture= [[Gothic Revival architecture|Neo-Gothic]], [[Chicago School (architecture)|Chicago School]]{{cite book|author1=Eric J. Hill|author2=John Gallagher|title=Aia Detroit: The American Institute of Architects Guide to Detroit Architecture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sZGskamYzjUC|accessdate=26 March 2013|year=2003|publisher=Wayne State University Press|isbn=978-0-8143-3120-0|page=102}} | added = July 27, 2005 | governing_body = Private | refnum=05000737 }} | references = {{ctbuh|10580}}{{emporis|118551}}{{skyscraperpage|958}}{{structurae|s0027666}}{{NRISref|2008a}} }} The '''Cadillac Tower''' is a 40-story, {{convert|133.4|m|abbr=on}} [[Gothic Revival architecture|Neo-Gothic]] [[skyscraper]] designed by the [[architectural firm]] of Bonnah & Chaffee at 65 Cadillac Square in [[Downtown Detroit|Downtown]] [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], not far from [[Renaissance Center]]. The building's materials include [[terra cotta]] and [[brick]]. It was built in 1927 as '''Barlum Tower'''. At the top of the tower is a tall [[guyed mast]] for local radio stations [[WMXD]], [[WDTW-FM]] and television station [[WLPC-CD]]. It was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2005. == History== Cadillac Tower was the first building outside [[New York City]] and [[Chicago]] to have 40 floors, including two below ground. The building also houses the city of Detroit's Planning and Development Department, and its Recreation Department. Cadillac Tower's decorative cornices and parapets are of varying heights. The corner spires rise to a height of {{convert|130|m|abbr=on}}, and the spires at the middle façade rise to the same height of the mechanical penthouse at {{convert|133.4|m|abbr=on}}. From 1994 to 2000, one side of the building featured a 14-story mural of [[Detroit Lions]] star player [[Barry Sanders]]. The mural was retired after a six-year deal with [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] expired. That mural was then replaced with one of [[Detroit Red Wings]] star [[Steve Yzerman]]. Currently the building features an ad for the [[MGM Grand Detroit]] Casino featuring a lion. In January 2008, the City of Detroit and Cadillac Tower's owner Northern Group, Inc., announced plans for [[Cadillac Centre]], a $150-million mixed-use residential entertainment-retail complex attached to the skyscraper. Designed by architect Anthony Caradonna, the contemporary steel and glass 24-story center would have filled in the currently vacant Monroe Block adjacent to [[Campus Martius Park|Campus Martius]]. This project was put on indefinite hold ultimately being replaced by Meridian Health Plan's future headquarters.{{cite web | author=Daniel Duggan | title=Detroit Economic Growth Corp. ends Cadillac Centre deal | url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20081006/FREE/810060277/ | publisher=Crains Detroit Press | date=6 October 2008 | accessdate=6 October 2012}} ==Gallery== File:CadillaclookingupDetroit.jpg|Looking up from [[Cadillac Square Park|Cadillac Square]] File:CadillacTowerDetroit2.jpg| File:CadillacTowerDetroit.jpg|Cadillac Tower from Greektown File:CadillacSquareParkdetroit.jpg|[[Cadillac Square Park|Cadillac Square]] File:CadillacTowerDetroit3.jpg| ==See also== *[[List of tallest buildings in Detroit]] * Other buildings designed by Bonnah & Chaffee: ** [[Lawyers Building]] ** [[Merchants Building]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{Cite book |author1=Hill, Eric J. |author2=John Gallagher | title=AIA Detroit: The American Institute of Architects Guide to Detroit Architecture | year=2002 | publisher=Wayne State University Press | isbn=0-8143-3120-3}} *Kvaran, Einar Einarsson, ''Architectural Sculpture of America'', unpublished manuscript. *{{Cite book | author=Meyer, Katherine Mattingly and Martin C.P. Guide Revised Edition | year=1980 | publisher=Wayne State University Press | isbn=0-8143-1651-4}} *{{Cite book | author=Sharoff, Robert | title=American City: Detroit Architecture | publisher=Wayne State University Press | year=2005 | isbn=0-8143-3270-6 | authorlink=Robert Sharoff}} *{{Cite book |author1=Savage, Rebecca Binno |author2=Greg Kowalski | title=Art Deco in Detroit (Images of America) | publisher=Arcadia | year=2004 | isbn=0-7385-3228-2}} ==External links== *[http://www.ctwr.com/index.html Official '''Cadillac Tower''' website] {{Downtown Detroit}} {{Architecture of metropolitan Detroit}} {{National Register of Historic Places listings in Wayne County, Michigan}} [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Detroit]] [[Category:Downtown Detroit]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1927]] [[Category:Office buildings on the National Register of Historic Places in Michigan]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Detroit]] [[Category:Historic district contributing properties in Michigan]] [[Category:1927 establishments in Michigan]] [[Category:1920s architecture in the United States]] [[Category:Gothic Revival architecture in Michigan]] [[Category:Chicago school (architecture)]]
